chapter.title: applications for Switchers
chapter.para: This section will highlight and explain some of the applications available in Ubuntu that are similar to standard stools on other operating systems, and allow for doing tasks like word processing, image manipulation and video, media players, web browsing, local area networking, and instant messaging. Many of these applications look and act similar to their counterparts on other operating systems.

sect1.title: Office Software
sect1.para: The Open Office package is suite of tools for word processing, spreadsheet creation, presentations, academic writing and other document creation common to an office. Allot of the tasks you might do in the Microsoft Office suite on Windows can be done using Open Office. The basic layout and functionality of the two suites is very similar. All Open Office applications can be found under &open-office;.

The word processing component of Open Office is called Open Office Writer. This program has it's own internal document format, but can also read and write Microsoft Word documents (.doc files) and Microsoft Word template documents (.dot files).

The spreadsheet component of Open Office is called Open Office Spreadsheet. This program has it's own internal document format, but can also read and write Microsoft Excel documents (.xls, .xlw files) and Microsoft Excel template documents (.xlt files).

The presentation component of Open Office is called Open Office Presentation. This program also has it's own internal format, but can also read and write Microsoft PowerPoint documents (.ppt, .pps files) and Microsoft PowerPoint template files (.pot files).

All Open Office documents can also be exported to Portable Document Format (.pdf files) to ensure portability and consistency of layout across platforms and PDF Reader applications such as Acrobat Reader.

sect1.title: Image Manipulation and Video Software
sect1.para: The Gimp, which stands for The GNU Image Manipulation Program, is a program for drawing, painting and editing images. Many of the tools and plugins available in The Gimp are similar to the ones in Adobe Photoshop, or other bitmap based editors. The Gimp also provides scriptable operations and manipulation with bindings to various open source scripting languages.

The Gimp has support for reading and writing a variety of media types including proprietary formats such as those of Adobe Photoshop (.psd files). Support for scanners and printers is also available. There are Allot of other tools for image manipulation covering a massive range of formats, though The Gimp is one of the only applications that presents its tools and functionality through a Graphical User Interface similar to products on other platforms. The Gimp is available from the 'main' repository from within Synaptic Package Manager (see for more information).

sect1.title: Media Players
sect1.para: Ubuntu has a wide variety of tools for manipulating, formatting and editing digital video. As there are many patent issues and fierce protection of proprietary formats in digital media, Ubuntu GNU/Linux does not provide support for all the known formats that are common on other platforms in the standard distribution. Ubuntu comes with media players that don't support the most popular media formats used in other operating systems (mp3, windows media, divx to name a few). This is hard to get used to if you are coming to Ubuntu from Microsoft Windows or OSX.
